properties.title: A sanctuary for at-risk birds
properties.teaser: Wolf Island: the low-lying barrier islands off limits to the public, but teeming with at-risk, threatened and endangered birds.
properties.alt: A sandy beach with a tuft of vegetation following a jetty.
properties.caption: Wolf Island. Photo by Nicole Vidal, USFWS.

properties.title: Many partners work together to protect “the Amazon of the South” for generations to come
properties.teaser: It meanders 137 miles through the wild heart of Georgia, a blackwater beauty that nourishes longleaf pine forests, cypress swamps, saltwater estuaries and the barrier islands that protect the Atlantic coast and migratory birds alike.
properties.alt: The sun sets over a bright green salt marsh.
properties.caption: Salt marsh along the Altamaha River. Photo by Nicole Vidal, USFWS.

properties.title: Longleaf pine to the rescue
properties.teaser: Just upriver from Altama Plantation, Sansavilla has taken on almost mythical status among conservationists. It was the corridor’s missing piece, a 19,500-acre chunk of land finally cobbled together last year by the Service, the state, the military, TNC and the Conservation Fund.
properties.alt: Tall, narrow, pine trees spaced about 25 feet apart with very sparse, dry grass in the understory.
properties.caption: Longleaf pine is a fire-dependent ecosystem.

properties.title: A gem for hunters and hikers alike
properties.teaser: Altama Plantation is perhaps the most critical, and intriguing, piece of property along the entire Altamaha River corridor.
properties.alt: An open gate surrounded by live oaks covered in Spanish moss.
properties.caption: Atama Plantation. Photo by Nicole Vidal, USFWS.

properties.title: The military embraces conservation
properties.teaser: U.S. Marine Corps jets and helicopters rain thousand-pound bombs and 30-caliber bullets on a slice of the Altamaha River corridor. Gopher tortoises, flatwood salamanders and eastern indigo snakes benefit mightily.
properties.alt: Two men standing in front of a beige tank riddled with bullet holes.
properties.caption: A tank littered with bullet holes at Townsend bombing range. Photo by Nicolve Vidal, USFWS.

properties.title: Local landowner fights for the Altamaha
properties.teaser: “God put it here a long time ago,” NeSmith preached, “and it’s on loan to my family and me and we want to do our part to make sure it remains a clean, safe environment for our great, great, great, great grandchildren.”
properties.alt: A gentlman with gray hair poses for the camera with a smile and his arms crossed.
properties.caption: Mr. Dink NeSmith has a special relationship with the Altamaha River. Photo by Nicole Vidal, USFWS.
